message.content:
cs.HC, cs.CY, cs.LG, cs.IR, cs.SI 

This paper discusses the use of user interfaces, pattern recognition, and ubiquitous computing to enhance personal health. The focus is on developing quantitative methods to guide individuals towards their health goals, which suggests a human-computer interaction (cs.HC) perspective. The use of ubiquitous computing to monitor environmental exposures and actuate timely interventions suggests a cybernetics (cs.CY) perspective. The proposal to combine events recognized by different ubiquitous systems and derive actionable causal relationships from an event ledger suggests a machine learning (cs.LG) perspective. The need to understand user habits and teleport this understanding between applications suggests an information retrieval (cs.IR) perspective. Finally, the proposal to enhance the user experience by leveraging event relationships suggests a social and information networks (cs.SI) perspective.
